bibl.title: Letter from S. M. Sparkman to George Miller Sternberg, June 13, 1901

div1.p: Sparkman encourages the printing of several thousand copies of “The Etiology of Yellow Fever” so that the people of the Gulf Coast can be informed of the mosquito theory. Sparkman realizes that it is very important that the yellow fever issue be cleared up, as there are numerous variant theories about the cause of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from S. M. Sparkman to George Miller Sternberg, June 13, 1901
div1.opener:
HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES.
WASHINGTON.
Tampa, Fla., June 13, 1901.
Gen. Geo. M. Sternberg,
Surgeon General, U.S.A.,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Sir,
div1.p:
I have yours of the 7th inst., and note that you had sent me
under separate cover ten copies of the report on The Etiology of
Yellow Fever, for which I wish to thank you.

I wrote you, by the way, while in Washington the other day
suggesting that another print of this document be made. I did
this, of course, without intending to do more than to make the sug-
gestion. I think it is a document that all the physicians in Flor-
ida should have, and many of the leading men. The investigations
have been carried along a line so different from that which has
been followed before, and intending to demonstrate a theory as to
the spreading of yellow fever so widely at variance with ideas pre-
viously held, that I think all the people along the Gulf Coast
of the United States should be informed on the subject. So I real-
ly hope you may see your way clear to have several thousand copies
of this report printed.
div1.closer:
Yours very truly, S. M. Sparkman M.C. Fla.
OFFICE OF SURGEON GENERAL,
